speaker: Clinician
text: Lab panel’s back: A1C already dipped from 8.6% to 7.7% after four semaglutide 0.25-mg injections—nice progress, and your creatinine stayed 1.0.

speaker: Clinician
text: Guideline says we step up to 0.5 mg next Sunday unless nausea worsens; have you had any vomiting, or merely the mild post-meal fullness?

speaker: Clinician
text: Recall glyburide is out of the pillbox, so lows should be rare; still keep glucose tabs in the sax case for emergencies.

speaker: Clinician
text: A quick safety note: aspirin 81 mg daily stays, no generic swaps; and we’ll continue flagging the sulfa allergy in every electronic script.

speaker: Clinician
text: Insurance still rejected the prior-auth for month two, but I secured three sample pens—that covers twelve weeks while appeals grind.

speaker: Patient
text: I’m, uh, relieved the sugar’s better, but I’m angry the insurer keeps tossing my file around. I poked through the FDA sheet myself—dose escalation is standard—so why should I beg for it? Also, yesterday after lunch my meter flashed 62; I chewed two glucose tabs like you said, but it scared me. Did stopping glyburide not fix that? Plus, the tinnitus spiked—could that be from semaglutide or something else?

speaker: Clinician
text: A 62 reading is borderline, but quick glucose tabs were correct. With glyburide gone, that dip likely came from delayed breakfast rather than semaglutide.

speaker: Clinician
text: Let’s still advance to 0.5 mg; inject Sunday morning in the thigh, hold button ten seconds, then refrigerate the pen cap for reuse.

speaker: Clinician
text: Because hearing the glucometer beep is tricky, set the vibration alert as backup; keep the display light bright for easy midnight checks.

speaker: Clinician
text: On aspirin, small bruises on forearms are expected; call only if purple patches exceed a guitar pick in size or if nosebleeds persist.

speaker: Clinician
text: I’ll fax the appeal now, note the glyburide stop, and schedule repeat labs plus an ophthalmology check in six weeks—anything else urgent?

speaker: Patient
text: Just one more thing, doc: the glaucoma drops ran out three days early because my fingers shook and I spilled some. The pharmacy wants a new prescription date, and I feel foolish asking again. Also, my niece worries semaglutide might clash with the lisinopril for my kidneys; I told her you’re monitoring labs, but can you reassure her so she stops hovering? She googled ‘renal failure’ last night and had me up till 2 a.m.
